question: Iodoform test gives a positive yellow precipitate with compounds containing which groups?
Addition of HBr to propene in the presence of peroxides gives 1-bromopropane as the major product instead of 2-bromopropane. This is because:
options: \text{Peroxides generate Br}^\bullet\text{; it adds to terminal carbon (less hindered) giving more stable radical at C2}
\text{Peroxides generate Br}^-\text{; it attacks the terminal carbon by SN2}
\text{Peroxides stabilise the secondary carbocation at C1}
answer: \text{Peroxides generate Br}^\bullet\text{; it adds to terminal carbon (less hindered) giving more stable radical at C2}
tip: Peroxide effect applies ONLY to HBr, not HCl or HI. Mechanism is free radical, not ionic. Br radical adds to terminal C → secondary radical at C2 → H adds to C2 → 1-bromopropane (anti-Markovnikov).

question: In SN1 reactions, partial racemisation occurs rather than complete racemisation. The correct reason is:
options: \text{Both frontal and backside attack occur on the planar carbocation, but backside is slightly preferred}
\text{Only backside attack occurs on the planar carbocation}
\text{The nucleophile attacks only from the front}
\text{The carbocation formed is tetrahedral, not planar}
answer: \text{Both frontal and backside attack occur on the planar carbocation, but backside is slightly preferred}
tip: Complete racemisation needs exactly 50:50 frontal and backside attack. Since the leaving group still partially shields one face even after departure, backside is slightly favoured — giving partial racemisation with slight excess of inverted product.

question: Vinyl chloride is far less reactive toward SN reactions, while benzyl chloride is far MORE reactive than ordinary alkyl chlorides in SN1. Which combination correctly explains BOTH?
options: \text{Vinyl: C-Cl has partial double bond character (resonance); Benzyl: carbocation resonance-stabilised by ring}
\text{Vinyl: sp}^2 \text{ carbon is larger; Benzyl: sp}^3 \text{ carbon is smaller}
\text{Vinyl: Cl is a poor leaving group; Benzyl: Cl is a better leaving group than usual}
\text{Vinyl: steric hindrance at sp}^2\text{; Benzyl: no steric hindrance at sp}^3
answer: \text{Vinyl: C-Cl has partial double bond character (resonance); Benzyl: carbocation resonance-stabilised by ring}
tip: Vinyl chloride: lone pair on Cl overlaps with pi bond → C-Cl acquires double bond character → very hard to break. Benzyl chloride: loss of Cl gives benzyl carbocation with 4 resonating structures across the ring → highly stable → SN1 very fast.
